content.title: Folate Deficiency
content.summary: Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia identical to B12 deficiency through impaired DNA synthesis. However, unlike B12 deficiency, folate deficiency does NOT cause neurological manifestations. The body's folate stores are limited (3-4 months), so deficiency develops more rapidly than B12 deficiency.
key_points: Causes megaloblastic anemia identical to B12 deficiency
NO neurological symptoms - key differentiator from B12 deficiency
Limited body stores deplete in 3-4 months vs 3-6 years for B12
Elevated homocysteine but NORMAL methylmalonic acid (MMA)
Common causes: poor diet, alcoholism, pregnancy, medications (methotrexate, phenytoin)
content.statement: Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia through impaired thymidine synthesis and DNA replication, developing more rapidly than B12 deficiency due to limited body stores, and notably lacking the neurological manifestations seen with B12 deficiency.

explanation.intuition: Think of folate as the 'one-carbon shuttle' - it carries single carbon units needed to make the building blocks of DNA (thymidine). Without it, cells that divide rapidly (blood cells, GI epithelium) cannot replicate their DNA properly.
explanation.key_insight: Unlike B12 deficiency, folate deficiency does not affect myelin synthesis, so neurological symptoms are absent. The key differentiator is that MMA is normal in folate deficiency (only elevated in B12 deficiency).
explanation.technical_details: Tetrahydrofolate (THF) accepts and donates one-carbon units essential for: (1) Thymidine synthesis (dUMP → dTMP via thymidylate synthase), (2) Purine synthesis, (3) Methionine regeneration from homocysteine. Methotrexate blocks dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), preventing THF regeneration.

definitions_glossary.folate: Vitamin B9, a water-soluble B vitamin essential for DNA synthesis and one-carbon metabolism
definitions_glossary.tetrahydrofolate: The active form of folate serving as a one-carbon carrier in biosynthetic reactions
definitions_glossary.methylenetetrahydrofolate: THF derivative that donates a carbon for thymidine synthesis
definitions_glossary.thymidylate_synthase: Enzyme converting dUMP to dTMP using methyleneTHF, essential for DNA synthesis
definitions_glossary.dihydrofolate_reductase: Enzyme regenerating THF from DHF; target of methotrexate
definitions_glossary.megaloblast: Abnormally large erythroid precursor with immature nucleus due to impaired DNA synthesis
definitions_glossary.homocysteine: Amino acid elevated in both B12 and folate deficiency
definitions_glossary.methylmalonic_acid: Metabolite elevated ONLY in B12 deficiency; normal in folate deficiency
definitions_glossary.neural_tube_defects: Congenital malformations (spina bifida, anencephaly) prevented by periconceptional folate
definitions_glossary.folic_acid: Synthetic form of folate used in supplements and fortification
definitions_glossary.leucovorin: 5-formylTHF, used as 'folate rescue' after methotrexate therapy
definitions_glossary.MTHFR: Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase; common polymorphism affects folate metabolism

pathophysiology.mechanism: Impaired thymidine and purine synthesis causing defective DNA replication
key_pathways: Without folate → Defective DNA synthesis → Megaloblastic erythropoiesis
Folate deficiency → Cannot regenerate methionine → Elevated homocysteine

laboratory_findings: Low serum folate (<3 ng/mL) or low RBC folate (<140 ng/mL)
NORMAL methylmalonic acid (key differentiator from B12)
diagnostic_criteria.bone_marrow: Megaloblastic changes identical to B12 deficiency

differential_diagnosis: Vitamin B12 deficiency (check MMA and B12 level)

folate_replacement.duration: Until deficiency corrected and underlying cause addressed
folate_replacement.response: Reticulocytosis in 5-7 days, anemia corrects in 1-2 months

treatment_options.critical_warning: ALWAYS exclude B12 deficiency before treating with folate - folate can improve hematologic parameters while allowing neurological damage to progress

prevention.fortification: Mandatory folic acid fortification in flour in >80 countries
prevention.pregnancy: 400-800 μg daily periconceptional to prevent neural tube defects

drug_interactions: Methotrexate - folate antagonist; leucovorin rescue used

definition.@value: A nutritional deficiency causing megaloblastic anemia due to impaired DNA synthesis from lack of folate, characterized by absence of neurological manifestations and normal methylmalonic acid levels

scopeNote.@value: Distinguished from B12 deficiency by normal MMA and absence of neurological symptoms

learning_objectives: Describe folate's role in one-carbon metabolism and DNA synthesis
Differentiate folate deficiency from B12 deficiency using MMA levels
Identify clinical conditions and medications causing folate deficiency
Explain why folate supplementation before B12 exclusion is dangerous
Describe folate's role in preventing neural tube defects
clinical_pearls: Normal MMA with elevated homocysteine = folate deficiency (not B12)
Always check B12 before treating folate deficiency to avoid masking B12 deficiency
Folate stores deplete in 3-4 months vs 3-6 years for B12
Alcoholism is most common cause in developed countries
Periconceptional folate reduces neural tube defect risk by 70%
RBC folate is more accurate than serum folate for chronic deficiency
common_misconceptions: Folate and B12 deficiency are interchangeable - they're not; B12 deficiency has neurological consequences
Serum folate is the best test - RBC folate better reflects tissue stores
Treating anemia is sufficient - must address underlying cause

citations.authors: Bailey LB, Stover PJ, McNulty H, et al.
citations.title: Biomarkers of Nutrition for Development—Folate Review
Megaloblastic anemias
citations.journal: Hematology Am Soc Hematol Educ Program
